comments.commentBody:
I actually carry a tin with me to take my leftovers, and restauranteurs are happy to see that; if more people did it, there would be less paper and plastic waste.

I also carry a titanium backpacker's spork with me, but so far the only way I can get them not to stuff plastic utensils in my bag is to tell them more than once I don't need them; eventually it may catch on.

Do you realize what a garden-variety diagnosis "sociopath" is?  It's practically  meaningless except in the DSM-IV manual or similar, and certainly not a bar to anything anyone in America wants to legally purchase, or adopt, or mentor, etc.

The National Gun Registry can only screen those who have been adjudicated mentally ill or are felons. Only a court can declare a person excluded from receiving constitutional rights. Just being weird isn't enough to label a person mentally ill. It appears that Dear was never convicted of a felony which would have left him off the list as well.

The response from the Republican right and the gun establishment has been a clockwork pinning of the attack on mental illness. The National Gun Registry is supposed to screen for mental illness, isnt it?

These people complain day in, day out that the President isn't keeping us safe. If President Obama had been keeping us even half as safe from terrorists as the NRA's gun registry scheme has been keeping us from "mental illness", ISIS would be flying their black flag over the Capitol by now.
He is, actually: a network created and nurtured by the Religious Right and the  Republican Party via Fox News, hate radio and other eager little helpers.

If random people were blowing up gun shops around the country as often as they attack abortion providers, or killing gun dealers to prevent people from exercising their legal right to purchase firearms, the usual suspects would be falling all over themselves to label them terrorists -- and rightly so. Terrorism doesn't have to be coordinated, it only has to be violence intended to intimidate those who don't agree with them. These killers fit the bill.

Thanks for the definitions, everyone, but you miss my point entirely.  This fellow is not consciously a member of a terrorist cell like the one in Belgium/Paris.  To call him so allows politicians to deflect attention away from what this man's solo act really is -- a product of what the Republican party is sowing into our daily fabric of life:  Guns guns guns.  Religious zealotry.  Opposition to social assistance.  I agree that it's all terrifying, and I know many others feel as this fellow did, and that they work in league.  But if you want to use the word "terrorism" in this particular case, apply it to those right-wing politicians who create fear and anger out of whole cloth to scare everyone into giving them votes that help them take their ideological extremism even further.

No, this is not terrorism.  Terrorism has a long-range plan to instill fear for purposes of societal control, with many perpetrators working in league to those ends.  This man was part of no such network.  He is a one-off nut job of the wholly American gun-happy, religious zealot variety, all of whom are inspired and enabled by -- yes, America -- right-wing causes célèbre, regardless of whether even the man himself knows it.  Republicans are weaving violence and hatred into the American fabric every day.  The subliminal effects emerge in guys like Robert Dear.  More to follow, especially if you vote for sheer demagogues shilling the evangelicals and genuflecting to the NRA . . .
First, dismantle HPPA, Larry.  Can't get pro-active on these issues otherwise.
Martin, I don't see TMI jn the puzzle.

By the way he didn't want to die. If he had wanted to die one would have thought he had ample opportunity to make that happen. He could have shot himself, for instance. Today, with a nice shave and what I assume is a bullet proof vest, am I imagining things or does he look rather pleased with himself?
Hate speech isn't protected by the First Amendment.

"Do we remove the positive freedoms in order to stop the negative ones?"

Guns are in no way a positive 'freedom', they are weapons of death, they make killing far too easy & are good for nothing.

The gun lobby is defending an addiction.
Their positions don't follow logic, no gang of gun enthusiasts could fight off the US military if it went rogue & staged a coup.

Researchers need to investigate the neurochemical conditioning of gun enthusiasts.

It's a seduction that starts in youth, develops into a powerful compulsion, sustained by fictions about safety, rights, hunting etc.

Watch a gun-enthusiast fondling a new toy in the village gun shop (ours is run by the adjacent liquor store, only successful retailer in the village), and you'll often witness the palpable wiled-eyed dopamine rush.

The same breathless rapture in hunting videos on YouTube just after the killing.

It is primal; danger, noise, death, power, precision gadgetry, so many things guys are turned on by wrapped up into a hand tool.

You won't be able to argue logic or law with an addict. Best approach is to identify they neurochemistry of gun enthusiasts with the addiction they are driven by, then like all other dangerous addictions, deal with it as a disease.

The best solution is to regulate ammo to smithereens. We need firearms out of our lives.
I wonder what kind of corporal punishment he got as a child. (Not that that would excuse it, but I'm still quite curious.) I bet life wasn't a picnic at home when he was a kid.

Yup.

Means? NRA and their Republican allies.

Motive? "Pro-life" and their Republican allies.

Opportunity? OK, can't blame them for that. Then they must be blameless.

If we were to take the logic of my state's governor, Scott Walker, and others of his ilk, we would be closing our nation's and state's borders to individuals with similar profiles as this domestic terrorist, Dear, Jr. - White, Christian male.  Those who fit this profile, who remain in their current states of residence would be put on law enforcement and TSA lists.
there are still far too many pitiful females who honestly feel that they're nothing without a man--desperate choices , soon regretted.

If you'd take a look at the Chinese article, linked right below the title of the article, you'll see that he is 坚果兄弟, not 建国兄弟.

It is plausible that he chose this nutty pseudonym because of its likeness to the patriotic name.

Maybe if this guy's face weren't the first thing I have to look at every time I open the NY Times app on my phone, losers like him wouldn't be so sure that, whatever else happens, if they shoot up a lot of people, they'll at least be really really famous.

It's been almost three years since the Sandy Hook school shooting. Many people thought that when 26 people (20 of them young children) were massacred in an elementary school, that surely Congress would pass tougher, more meaningful gun control laws. Nothing happened. When people of faith were murdered during a prayer meeting at a church in Charleston this past June -- murdered by a young man they reportedly welcomed into their midst -- many people thought that would surely lead to tougher gun control laws. Nothing happened. With this shooting at a Planned Parenthood clinic, it seems that talk of gun control runs a distant third to discussion of (1) whether to call the shooting an act of domesti  terrorism and (2) whether the shooter was provoked by the hateful speech coming from the right.

What's wrong with this picture?  We already feel there's nothing that can be done about this sort of domestic right wing violence.  I guess there will soon be someone who manages to kill a lot more than 3, and then we might even get hopeful that this time something will happen.  But again, even then, whether it is 3 or 30, it doesn't matter to Americans enough to get them to vote.

Dear Ken

Jian in first tone and guo in third tone mean nut. Check your mandarin please

He sounds similar to the middle-aged white guy who killed those three young Muslim students in North Carolina. The first narrative about his motive, rather than bigotry, was his obsession about parking spaces in his apartment complex.

Oh please. There are many fine professional politicians in Washington, Dems and Repubs. I don't want Joe from the hardware store making foreign policy. There is some learning' involved, and it doesn't come overnight. Some are incompetent? Vote 'em out!
But at least Republicans respect the Bill of Rights and the first and second amendments.
You are absolutely right!

It's been obvious to me for decades, and should now be obvious to everyone, that neither party has any respect for democracy and both parties' greatest fear is that government by the people, of the people and for the people will be established. This is what happens when you let people make careers out of politics; it's human nature to put your career first, and everything else second.

Presidents are elected by choosing electors in each state, as you know.  Trump supporters are concentrated in states that Ds will not win in any case.  1964 will look like a close contest in comparison.

What has bothered me most, as it suggests a hidden cabal that makes the final decision on who will lead our nation, are the assured, confident and perhaps absolutist statements of senior Republicans to the effect that Trump will not and could not win the nomination nor the general election. It is as though they have gotten word from the gnomes of Zurich or the Bilderbergers or another of those shadowy, mostly mythical groups telling them with certainty that Trump will not make it. I cannot and will not believe any such thing. However, I also remain unconvinced that these "Woe is me!" comments from the "powers that be" (but apparently are not) are legitimate. People like the Kochs don't just lick their wounds and go away quietly; they are mad, rabid, raving dogs who will fight with desperation and every means available to gain what they want, and are now planning to do so.Trump, too, will fight them tooth and nail, and I think he knows who they are.

Trump's comments have galvanized the electorate as no one has since Huey Long. As the scion of a family that held elected officer as Republicans for 110 years straight, and defeated Tammany Hall in 1909, I urge Republicans a) not to panic, and b) not to feel that Donald Trump will wreck the party. Inevitably, after the dust settles, Americans keep on going forward as they always have, and the Republicans, in the White House or not, will have the same shot at voters they have always had. That's not a bad thing, men - relax!
Because the electoral college actually elects the president, not the popular vote, and the electoral college was instituted specifically to avoid the people electing someone like Donald Trump?

The secret is that the 1 percent are the socialist globalists who want to do away with the constitution and nation states in general. Look at the electoral map. It's not because the elites are noble and the working people are stupid.

The GOP invited the Tea Party, Libertarians, and others into their big tent. Now the baby elephants are ripping the tent to shreds, and the RINOs, neocons, and 1% are rueing the day. Too bad, they are killing the party of Lincoln. I got a feeling Lincoln wouldn't have wanted the GOP to end as a party that can't and won't govern responsibly.

Today I had my five-year CT for throat cancer, and when my radiation oncologist entered the room afterward he announced, "You're cured!" Not in remission, not NED (no evidence of disease, as all my other scans have been), but cured, the good "c" word. Just as I'd thought.

No, I don't think there is any one cure, not even necessarily for any one cancer. It can have different causes, and they can require varying treatments. Many folks get my cancer from tobacco use, but I didn't. Many get it as a result of HPV, but not me. When I was diagnosed it was considered not a hereditary cancer, but after going through radiation I found out that my great grandfather died of it. And now there is research suggeting there might be a genetic component. The more we understand the more there is to know.

But there is a way to prevent many cases of throat cancer, and cancers of the cervix, vulva, penis, and rectum as well. All that's needed is a series of immunizations for HPV. Trust me, you don't want your kids and grandkids to have to go through treatment for this cancer.

I promised Dr. Fairbanks that I'd be on this soapbox from now on.

Paul, the New Deal-era 'portfolio' of policies (fixed exchange rates, Reg Q, mildly pro-labor bias, fiscal management of macro imbalances, etc) were indeed responsible for the broad-based growth of that period. But they were predicated on two global factors: The quasi-public international financial order and the competitiveness of US firms in global markets. Both of these were utterly undermined before Reagan stepped into office. It is hard to see how the 'portfolio' could be brought back into play given the liberal international financial order and the much more competitive global landscape.
